discussion.p: unique_ptr guarantees that it will not invoke its deleter if it stores a null pointer, which is useful for deleters that must not be called with a null pointer e.g.

However, shared_ptr does invoke the deleter if it owns a null pointer, which is a silent change in behaviour when transferring ownership from unique_ptr to shared_ptr. That means the following leads to undefined behaviour:
Peter Dimov's suggested fix is to construct an empty shared_ptr from a unique_ptr that contains a null pointer.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N3936.

blockquote.pre: template <class Y, class D> shared_ptr(unique_ptr<Y, D>&& r);

blockquote.p: -33- Effects: Equivalent to shared_ptr() if r.get() == nullptr, otherwise equivalent to shared_ptr(r.release(), r.get_deleter()) when D is not a reference type, otherwise shared_ptr(r.release(), ref(r.get_deleter())).
